channel.title: Networking :: Linux Reader
channel.description: CCNA Cisco to Juniper Cheat Sheet How to Study for the CCNA Exam My CCNA Notes Resources for Passing CCNA What to Learn After CCNA Juniper consoling_in_to_mx80_from_linux Juniper CLI Basics Junos Fundementals Paste Config on a Juniper Switch Toggle PoE on a Juniper Switch DNS and Time Synchronization How to Study for the CCNA Exam Networking Network Devices and Network Connections Resources for Passing CCNA What to Learn After CCNA The formatting and images of all of my networking notes go destroyed when migrating away from OneNote. But they still come in handy all of the time.

item.title: How to Study for the CCNA Exam
item.description: It took me a whopping 2 years to finish my CCNA! I kept giving up and quitting my studies for months at a time. Why? Because I couldn’t remember the massive amount of content covered in the CCNA. It felt hopeless. I could have done it in 6 month (or faster) if I knew how to study.

item.title: Networking Network Devices and Network Connections
item.description: Hostname, IP addressing, network protocols, network manager, tools, etc.

item.title: Resources for Passing CCNA
item.description: There are a lot of great CCNA resources out there. This list does not include all of them. Only the ones that I personally used to pass the CCNA 200-301 exam. Materials for CCNA are generally separated into 5 categories: Books Video courses Labs Practice test Flashcards Books Wendell Odom OCG Official cert guide library To me, this is the king of CCNA study materials. Some people do not like reading but this will give you more depth than any other resource on this list. Link.

item.title: What to Learn After CCNA
item.description: It’s easy to get overwhelmed with options after completing your CCNA. What do you learn next? If you are trying to get a job as a Network Engineer, you will want to check this out. I went through dozens of job listings that mentioned CCNA. Then, tallied up the main devices/vendors, certifications, and technologies mentioned. And left out anything that wasn’t mentioned more than twice. Core CCNA technologies such as LAN, WAN, OSPF, Spanning Tree, VLANs, etc. have been left out. The point here is to target the most sought after technologies and skills by employers. I also left out soft skills and any job that wasn’t a networking specific role.
